content: The "Bureau of Reclamation Small Conduit Hydropower Development and Rural Jobs Act" authorizes the Secretary to enter into contracts for water supply and sales of electric power, amending the Reclamation Project Act of 1939. The "Bureau of Reclamation Small Conduit Hydropower Development and Rural Jobs Act" authorizes the Secretary to offer leases of power privileges to irrigation districts or water users associations for small conduit hydropower projects. The Secretary must provide a reasonable time frame for acceptance or rejection of the lease offer. The Bureau of Reclamation offers a lease of power privilege to irrigation districts or water users associations for small conduit hydropower projects. The Power Resources Office will lead policy activities for small conduit hydropower development. The Western Area Power Administration and Bonneville Power Administration are not obligated under this subsection. The Bureau of Reclamation offers a lease of power privilege for small conduit hydropower projects. The lease does not obligate the Western Area Power Administration, Bonneville Power Administration, or Southwestern Power Administration to purchase or market the power produced. Water delivery and management by Bureau of Reclamation facilities remain unaffected, with power generation considered incidental to the original project purposes. The lease of power privilege is subject to the Secretary's judgment to ensure compatibility with project purposes. The Secretary must consult with the irrigation district or water users association before offering a lease of power privilege for conduit hydropower projects. Existing agreements and permits issued by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission are not affected by this subsection. The Bureau of Reclamation Small Conduit Hydropower Development and Rural Jobs Act applies to projects under the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, defining terms like 'conduit' and 'irrigation district'. The Bureau of Reclamation Small Conduit Hydropower Development and Rural Jobs Act defines terms like 'district', 'reserved conduit', and 'transferred conduit' in relation to irrigation and water conservation projects. The Bureau of Reclamation Small Conduit Hydropower Development and Rural Jobs Act defines 'small conduit hydropower' as a facility producing 5 megawatts or less of electric capacity.
